text: The thing that I just like to encourage founders and product managers and what have you is just don't be afraid of sales. There's a lot of people out there who would love to tell you a story that it's magical or like, "Oh, you've got to be a born seller," things like that and it's really not. Those people are just talking their book, if you will, and so just getting good at those behaviors, it's going to benefit you in a myriad of ways.
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Lenny asks Pete for his final pieces of wisdom about sales for founders and product managers. Pete emphasizes that sales isn't a mystical skill that requires natural talent, contrary to what some people claim. He explains that the people who perpetuate the myth that sales is magical are simply promoting their own interests or expertise. Pete argues that learning sales behaviors will benefit professionals in many ways, even beyond direct selling situations.
text_ko: 창업자(founders)나 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)분들께 드리고 싶은 말은, 영업(sales)을 너무 두려워하지 말라는 거예요. 영업이 마법 같다고 하거나 “타고난 판매자여야 해”라고 말하는 사람들이 많은데, 사실 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 그런 사람들은 자기 이익을 위해 그런 얘기를 하는 거고요. 그러니까 그런 행동들을 잘 익혀두면 여러모로 도움이 될 거예요.
text_zh: 我就是想鼓励那些创始人、产品经理什么的，千万别害怕销售这件事。外面有很多人会跟你说什么销售很神秘啦，或者"哎呀，你得天生就会卖东西"之类的话，其实根本不是这么回事。这些人就是在为自己说话罢了，所以你把这些销售技能练好了，对你各方面都有好处。
text_es: Lo que me gusta decirles a los fundadores y product managers y demás es simplemente que no le tengan miedo a las ventas. Hay mucha gente por ahí que te va a querer vender el cuento de que es algo mágico o que "ay, tienes que haber nacido para vender" y toda esa historia, pero la verdad es que no es así. Esa gente simplemente está defendiendo su negocio, ¿sabes? Así que ponerte bueno en esas habilidades te va a beneficiar de mil maneras.

text: Never mistake your lead gen for your business. I think the good news is that a lot of people took a lot of lumps there and folks have learned that, maybe Slack almost missed that, but then they brought in a bunch of Salesforce folks and other folks.
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Lenny asks Pete whether founders have to get good at sales, especially those building PLG (product-led growth) companies. Pete explains why many PLG companies eventually need to add sales teams to scale beyond their initial self-serve motion. He uses Dropbox as an example of a company that may have delayed building sales capabilities too long, and contrasts it with Slack which successfully added enterprise sales.
text_ko: 리드 생성(lead gen)을 당신의 비즈니스 그 자체로 착각하지 마세요. 좋은 소식은 많은 사람들이 그 과정에서 시행착오를 많이 겪으면서 배웠다는 거예요. 아마 슬랙은 그걸 거의 놓칠 뻔했는데, 결국 세일즈포스 출신 등 여러 사람들을 영입해서 바로잡았어요.
text_zh: 千万别把获客渠道当成你的核心业务。我觉得好消息是很多人在这方面都吃过亏，大家也都学到了教训。Slack可能差点在这上面栽跟头，但后来他们找来了一批Salesforce的人和其他行业老手。
text_es: Nunca confundas tu generación de leads (lead gen) con tu negocio real. Lo bueno es que mucha gente se pegó buenos golpes ahí y aprendió la lección. Slack casi la cagó con eso, pero luego trajeron a un montón de gente de Salesforce y otras empresas que sabían del tema.

text: The way to think about what sellers are is they're the microeconomic agents in the market that bring supply to demand rather than waiting for demand to find supply. They have supply in their back pocket and they run around trying to find people who ought to have the demand, maybe they have the demand right now, maybe they don't realize that they have the demand, and then they elucidate to them why they ought to have the demand.
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Lenny asks Pete to explain what "modern sales" means versus traditional or old-school sales. Pete reframes the perception of salespeople from the stereotypical "sleazy used car salesman" image to viewing them as economic facilitators. He describes modern sales as a more thoughtful, measurable approach where salespeople actively connect solutions to problems in the market, rather than waiting for customers to discover solutions on their own.
vocabulary_highlights: have supply in their back pocket
text_ko: 판매자를 이해하는 한 가지 방식은, 그들이 시장에서 수요가 공급을 찾아오길 기다리지 않고 공급을 수요 쪽으로 가져다주는 미시경제적 행위자들(microeconomic agents)이라고 보는 거예요. 판매자들은 공급을 항상 가지고 다니면서, 지금 당장 수요를 가지고 있거나 본인은 모를 수도 있는 사람들을 찾아다니고, 왜 그들이 그 수요를 가져야 하는지(또는 그 제품·서비스가 왜 필요한지)를 설명해줘요.
text_zh: 销售人员其实就是市场里的微观经济主体(microeconomic agents)，他们的作用是主动把供应推向需求，而不是坐等需求自己找上门。他们手里握着货源，到处跑着找那些应该有需求的人——有些人现在就有需求，有些人还没意识到自己有需求，然后销售就去给他们分析为什么他们应该有这个需求。
text_es: La forma de entender a los vendedores es que son los agentes microeconómicos del mercado que llevan la oferta hacia la demanda, en lugar de esperar a que la demanda encuentre la oferta. Tienen la oferta guardada bajo la manga y salen a buscar gente que debería tener esa demanda - tal vez ya la tienen, tal vez no se dan cuenta de que la tienen - y entonces les explican por qué deberían tenerla.

text: You really just can't do that, not for the first couple dozen customers, it's just not tenable. You lose that feedback loop, you lose the learnings of whether or not your message fits the market, all that sort of stuff. You're playing a game of telephone with that with a third party seller versus even you just want to keep that in one brain to start, then package it, and then when you have a repeatable while loop, a selling while loop, then package it and hand it to someone else.
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Pete explains why founders must do sales themselves initially rather than outsourcing it to hired salespeople. He describes founder-led sales as the natural sequel to customer development and product building phases. Pete argues that founders are uniquely positioned to become experts at selling their solution because they understand the problem and technology better than any third party could initially learn to.
text_ko: 그건 정말로 할 수 없어요, 처음 몇십 명의 고객을 위해서는 더더욱 그렇고요. 피드백 루프(feedback loop)를 잃게 되면, 메시지가 시장에 맞는지에 대한 배움도 놓치게 돼요. 그렇게 되면 제3자 판매자와 전화게임을 하는 것과 같고요. 처음에는 그 모든 걸 한 사람의 머릿속에 두고 시작한 다음, 패키징해서 반복 가능한 판매 루프(selling while loop)가 생기면 그때 다른 사람에게 넘기는 게 좋죠.
text_zh: 这样做真的不行，至少前几十个客户不能这么搞，根本站不住脚。你会失去反馈循环(feedback loop)，学不到你的信息是否符合市场需求，这些东西都没了。通过第三方销售就像在玩传话游戏一样，还不如一开始就自己掌控全局，等摸清套路了再打包。等你有了可重复的销售循环(selling while loop)，再包装好交给别人去做。
text_es: Simplemente no puedes hacer eso, no con los primeros veinte o treinta clientes, no es viable. Pierdes ese ciclo de retroalimentación (feedback loop), pierdes el aprendizaje de si tu mensaje realmente conecta con el mercado, todas esas cosas. Es como jugar al teléfono roto con un vendedor externo, cuando lo que realmente necesitas es mantener todo eso en una sola cabeza al principio, luego empaquetarlo, y cuando ya tengas un proceso repetible de venta, un bucle de venta (selling while loop) que funcione, ahí sí lo empaquetas y se lo pasas a alguien más.

text: What ends up happening is it's just a skill. You just start doing it, you start doing it, you start doing it, and you just become used to it, you become calloused. You're like, "I'm incorrigible now. You put me in an elevator, I can talk to anyone."
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Lenny asks Pete for his number one tip for getting better at sales. Pete first explains that sales requires a major mindset shift - from working with the same few people daily to meeting multiple new people every day and managing parallel conversations. He describes how this initially uncomfortable behavior becomes natural through repetition, comparing it to building calluses through repeated practice.
text_ko: 결국엔 그냥 기술이에요. 계속 하다 보면 자연스럽게 되고 익숙해져서 무뎌져요. 이제는 '아, 나 고쳐지지 않겠구나'라고 느낄 정도예요. 엘리베이터에 넣어놔도 누구하고든 얘기할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 结果就是这变成了一种技能。你就是不断地练，不断地练，不断地练，然后就习惯了，就练出厚脸皮了。你会想："我现在是没救了，把我扔电梯里，我跟谁都能聊。"
text_es: Lo que termina pasando es que simplemente se vuelve una habilidad. Empiezas a hacerlo, sigues haciéndolo, sigues haciéndolo, y te acostumbras completamente, te vuelves como inmune. Llegas al punto donde dices: "Ya no hay quien me pare. Me metes en un ascensor y puedo hablar con cualquiera."

text: As a seller, the way that I like to frame it to people is that you're a consultant that has a particular predilection for a given solution, your solution. Use Atrium as an example. Atrium's minimum ICP is probably SDRs plus AEs in an organization should probably be at 10 all the way up to 300. So, if someone shows up and they're like, "Man, I've got to get really good at sales, I need to buy your software, Pete," and I'm like, "Cool. How many salespeople do you have?" They're like, "I have one." I'll be like, "Man, I'm not going to sell you Atrium."
speaker: Pete Kazanjy
context: Lenny asks Pete about shifting mindset from trying to convince someone to buy something to trying to help them. Pete contrasts old-school sales (like "selling ice to an Eskimo") with modern sales where you act as a consultant with expertise in a particular solution. He gives a practical example of how he would actually refuse to sell Atrium to someone who doesn't fit their ideal customer profile, even if they want to buy.
text_ko: 판매자로서 제가 사람들에게 설명하는 방식은, 여러분이 특정 솔루션에 대한 선호가 있는 컨설턴트라는 거예요. 예를 들어 Atrium을 생각해보면, Atrium의 최소 ICP는 아마도 조직 내에서 SDR과 AE가 10명에서 300명 정도는 되어야 할 것 같아요. 그래서 누군가가 나타나서 "아, 나 정말 세일즈를 잘해야 해, 너희 소프트웨어를 사야겠어, Pete"라고 하면, 제가 "좋아, 세일즈맨이 몇 명이나 있어?"라고 물어볼 거예요. 그 사람이 "한 명 있어요"라고 대답하면, 저는 "아, Atrium은 팔지 않을 거야"라고 말할 거예요.
text_zh: 作为销售，我喜欢这样跟大家说：你其实就是个咨询顾问，只不过你对某个特定的解决方案情有独钟，也就是你自己的产品。拿Atrium举例吧，Atrium的最小理想客户画像(ICP)大概是一个组织里要有SDR加AE总共10到300人这样。所以如果有人过来跟我说："哥们，我得把销售搞好，我要买你的软件，Pete。"我就会问："行啊，那你们有多少销售？"他们说："就一个人。"我就会说："兄弟，那我不会卖Atrium给你的。"
text_es: Como vendedor, la forma en que me gusta planteárselo a la gente es que eres un consultor que tiene una preferencia particular por una solución específica, tu solución. Usa Atrium como ejemplo. El ICP mínimo de Atrium probablemente son SDRs más AEs en una organización que debería estar entre 10 hasta 300. Entonces, si llega alguien y me dice, "Oye, tengo que volverme muy bueno en ventas, necesito comprar tu software, Pete," y yo le digo, "Perfecto. ¿Cuántos vendedores tienes?" Y me responde, "Tengo uno." Le voy a decir, "Mira, no te voy a vender Atrium."
